executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Hospitals have a central role in healthcare delivery in the United States. As the frontline for specialized and emergency care, hospitals receive patient streams regardless of economic conditions, but rising incomes and broader insurance coverage facilitate access to elective care. Since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, hospitals have coped with persistent and unprecedented challenges to their resources, finances and workforce.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Hospitals Fight a Losing Battle Against the Pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising incomes, broader access to public and private insurance programs and the aging population's expanding medical needs sustained hospital patient volumes before the COVID-19 pandemic. Shortages of staff and essential medical equipment (PPE, ventilators) jeopardized hospitals' ability to treat patients during the pandemic. The sudden drop in patient volumes, rapidly rising costs and the physical and mental toll on hospital staff created instability.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Financial Pressures Challenge the Healthcare Landscape
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Dissipating COVID-19 concerns across the country didn't show up in hospitals. Instead, hospitals faced new challenges, pressuring their workforce, finances and supply chain. Funding relief that kept hospitals afloat fizzled out, sending over half of US hospitals into the red in 2022 as financial pressures mounted. For-profit hospitals didn't experience the same drop in profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Hospitals will confront the enormous strain the COVID-19 pandemic placed on the infrastructure, labor, supply chain and balance sheets. Cost pressures on labor, pharmaceuticals and supplies will trigger more consolidation activity. Pandemic relief kept smaller hospitals afloat during the pandemic, no additional relief programs are expected. Depressed profit

Healthcare delivery has been shifting over the past decade. Hospitals will remain central to the healthcare sector, but alternative care methods could be disruptive moving forward. Decentralized care takes patients away from hospitals. The rising popularity of urgent care clinics and health clinics inside nationwide retailers like CVS and Walmart are examples of this care model.
Hospitals will be vital in treating an aging population's increasingly complex health needs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Hospitals Will Evolve as Innovations Unfold
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As hospitals treat more Medicare patients, they'll become more reliant on these reimbursements as a revenue source. Any cuts to reimbursement rates by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid will directly impact hospitals. Patients who avoided care during the COVID-19 pandemic will strain hospitals more. Long periods of deferred care leads to more severe illnesses, so these patients will require extended inpatient stays and higher acuity care.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: New and Emerging Advances in Healthcare Technology
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Embracing technology can help hospitals alleviate the staff burnout and labor shortages characterizing them. AI-enabled software can automate administrative work that bogs down staff. Other advances – like robots – can also alleviate staff burden. Improvements in robotic surgery will lead to shorter hospital stays, while further innovations in robotics can have them perform routine tasks like food delivery and cleaning.

industry_definition: The Hospital industry includes operators licensed as general medical and surgical hospitals that provide surgical and nonsurgical diagnostic and medical treatment to inpatients. Hospitals maintain inpatient beds and usually provide other services, including outpatient, operating room and pharmacy services. The industry excludes psychiatric and other specialty hospitals.

key_trends: COVID-19 created unprecedented challenges for hospitals, with hospitals continuing to contend complex workforce, supply chain, operational and financial pressures.
Operating pressures have accelerated change in healthcare delivery. Hospitals have hastened their shift from inpatient to outpatient care and involvement in M&A activities.
Hospitals operate in one of the most regulated environments in the United States. A dizzying amount of federal, state and local laws; agencies; and regulators oversee hospitals.
COVID-19 relief and policies eased financial and operating pressures at hospitals. But as pandemic relief fizzes out, hospitals face an unprecedented financial strain.
Private insurers are hospitals' largest revenue source. Higher prices for commercial insurers and broader private insurance coverage translate into more revenue for hospitals.
Hospitals are undergoing a shift from inpatient to outpatient care.
Pressures from payers and reimbursement fluctuations are triggering the change to lower-cost outpatient settings.
Dense metropolitan areas have the most hospital beds. Large cities with high healthcare needs have more hospitals to keep people-to-bed ratios low.
Population hubs support hospital utilization. The Southeast has the largest population, warranting a greater need for hospitals to meet medical needs.
Hospitals are vital to healthcare delivery, limiting competition from other healthcare providers.

Changing dynamics in the healthcare sector are shifting how health services are delivered. Ambulatory surgery centers, urgent care and freestanding emergency departments could lessen the role of hospitals moving forward.
Even as consolidation by major hospital systems enhances market share, no hospital system holds more than 5.0% of the market.
Financial relief kept hospitals afloat during the COVID-19 pandemic, but margins fell as pandemic relief funds fizzled out in 2022.
Rising labor, supplies and drug costs are squeezing margins, creating an unprecedented financial strain on hospitals.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Private health insurance includes commercial insurance (PPO, HMO) and private health plans purchased directly or through a health insurance marketplace. Private insurers reimburse in-network hospitals for patient treatment. Prices are determined through contract negotiations between payors and providers. Exact prices by insurers vary widely and depend on a variety of factors. Larger hospital systems tend to have more power in negotiations.

Government insurers include Medicare and Medicaid. Medicare provides insurance benefits to people aged 65 and older or with disabilities; Medicaid administers benefits to qualifying individuals who can't afford healthcare. Laws and regulations set prices paid by Medicare and Medicaid programs via various payment schedules for different services.

Out-of-pocket payments include payments by patients for medical care not covered by insurance. This includes deductibles, copayments and coinsurance. Recent growth in out-of-pocket expenses stems from rising healthcare costs that outpace employee insurance benefits. Total out-of-pocket spending has also grown because of the increased use of medical services following the COVID-19 pandemic.

Other hospital revenue sources include reimbursements from various federal, state and local programs; workers' compensation; maternal and child health programs; the Department of Defense; the Department of Veterans Affairs; charitable contributions and miscellaneous private sources. Nonprofit and safety net hospitals receive more funding and government subsidies than for-profit entities.

products_and_services.product_description: Inpatient care includes overnight patient care received at a hospital. Historically, inpatient care was the status quo at hospitals. But, over the past decade, an ongoing effort to shift costly inpatient care into lower-cost outpatient care has changed this, disrupting the traditional revenue stream for hospitals. Still, inpatient care constitutes nearly half of total revenue.

Outpatient care refers to any service that doesn't require an overnight stay in a hospital (X-rays, mammograms, same-day surgery, lab work). Revenue hospitals receive from outpatient stays has been rising. Outpatient revenue is slated to exceed inpatient revenue for the first time in 2023.

Other hospital revenue sources include reimbursements from various federal, state and local programs; workers' compensation; maternal and child health programs; the Department of Defense; the Department of Veterans Affairs; charitable contributions and miscellaneous private sources.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Pressures from payers and reimbursement fluctuations are triggering the change to lower-cost outpatient settings.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Medical Advancements Facilitate Switch to Outpatient Care
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the shift away from inpatient care, an outcome of telemedicine, an uptick in ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) and new medical technologies. Advancements in medical technologies facilitate at-home care and reduce inpatient hospitalizations altogether.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-quarter of the US population resides in the Southeast region. As a central population hub, this region houses many hospitals to meet the medical needs of its population. Florida has the most hospitals in the region, an outcome of the state's population size and demographic makeup.

The West's share of hospitals falls closely in line with its share of the US population. The high concentration of hospitals in the region is primarily a result of population distribution. California has the highest number of hospitals in this region and the second-highest in the entire US (Texas has the largest amount).

The Mid-Atlantic's share of hospitals mirrors its share of the population. Pennsylvania and New York contribute substantially to the percentage of hospitals in this region. Densely populated cities in New York influence the number of hospitals in the state. New York City has more residents than North Dakota, Wyoming and Alabama combined, warranting a greater need for more hospitals. New York City has the most hospital beds in the country.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Hospitals must follow meet all of the criteria of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). HIPAA outlines how hospitals and healthcare providers can store, use and share patient healthcare information.

The Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) mandates audits of healthcare providers to ensure compliance with HIPAA. The HITECH Act strengthens HIPAA by incentivizing providers to adopt electronic health records (EHRs) and enforcing steeper penalties for noncompliance.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Anti-Kickback Statute and Physician Self-Referral Laws
regulations_points.regulation_description: The federal Anti-Kickback Statute prohibits the exchange of anything of value (financial incentives, low rents, excessive compensation) for the referral of any business reimbursable by federal healthcare programs (Medicare, Medicaid). Kickbacks promote overutilization of healthcare, create higher costs and corrupt decision-making by steering patients away from valid services. Physical self-referral law prohibits physicians from referring patients to a healthcare service if they or a family member have a financial relationship with that entity.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) makes payments to participating hospitals under its Medicare and Medicaid programs based on various formulas. Federal law mandates services hospitals render to Medicare and Medicaid patients meet professionally recognized standards. CMS provisions also ensure that the healthcare services are medically necessary and reimbursement claims are correctly filed.

The Hospital Readmissions Reduction Program (HRRP) requires the CMS to reduce payouts to care facilities that have excessive patient readmissions. The program monitors repeat patient admissions to hospitals participating with the CMS.

The No Surprises Act (NSA) established new federal protections against surprise medical bills. The NSA prohibits hospitals to bill patients more than the in-network cost-sharing amount; hospitals can no longer charge patients who inadvertently receive care from an out-of-network provider. The act has been in effect since January 1, 2022.

The 21st Century Cures Act gives patients' access to their electronic medical records and allow providers to select IT tools without excessive costs or technical barriers. Through the Act, healthcare providers at hospitals can make more informed decisions regarding patient care.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Rise Across the Board
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases account for an estimated 20.4% of revenue in 2023. Hospitals procure medical supplies and equipment at scale to keep costs low. The breadth of medical goods is vast, ranging from consumables, personal protective equipment, pharmaceuticals, durable medical equipment and surgical supplies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Drug costs are a rapidly growing expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In 2022, the AHA estimates that total drug expenses were 28.2% higher than pre-COVID levels. Factors affecting rising drug costs occur outside of the industry, but hospitals are forced to accept these price hikes since drugs are critical to patient care.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Inflation is also driving up what hospitals pay
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: While inflation has settled, hospitals are paying more for supplies than ever in 2023. Medicare spending cuts combined with payment increases

Wages are the primary expense for hospitals, comprising an estimated 34.8% of revenue in 2023. Recent wage hikes at hospitals stem from staffing shortages and wage inflation. Preexisting workforce shortages and pandemic-related burnout have pressured wages up, in addition to signing bonuses and additional benefits to attract and retain workers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Contract labor has also been on the rise
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Contracted labor comes at a higher cost than salaried employees, but it's been necessary to fill staff vacancies. Hospitals have to maintain appropriate staffing levels, so labor expenses have to rise high enough for providers to fill vacancies. High pay for clinicians is also essential to remain competitive and reduce patient backlogs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Hospitals rely on qualified staff for core functions
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Hospital systems rely on qualified staff for core functions (emergency, surgical, specialty care finance, HR). Ongoing critical staffing shortages jeopardize hospitals' ability to acquire and retain staff.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower.
However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.

The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Hospitals provide vital healthcare services and are the primary source of emergency and specialized care (intensive care, burn centers, cancer treatment, maternity care), limiting volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Hospitals are largest recipient of US healthcare spending
volatility_points.volatility_description: Hospitals are historically the largest recipient of US healthcare spending. Even when healthcare spending falls, hospitals' essential role in healthcare delivery warrants this level of expenditure.

Reimbursements by public and private sector insurance programs determine a hospital's revenue. Changes in these reimbursements (determined by a host of competing factors) can occur annually and produce significant consequences for hospitals.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Public vs private payer pricing differences
volatility_points.volatility_description: How public and private payors pay hospitals for healthcare services differs. Prices paid by commercial insurers are determined by negotiations, whereas laws and regulations mandate prices for public insurers. Pricing pressures that tilt in favor of the public or private payors cause volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Hospitals Shift Away From Inpatient Care
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Inpatient care includes overnight patient care received at a hospital. Historically, inpatient care was the status quo at hospitals. But, over the past decade, an ongoing effort to shift costly inpatient care into lower-cost outpatient care has changed this, disrupting the traditional revenue stream for hospitals. Still, inpatient care constitutes nearly half of total revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Medical Advancements Facilitate Switch to Outpatient Care
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the shift away from inpatient care, an outcome of telemedicine, an uptick in ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) and new medical technologies. Advancements in medical technologies facilitate at-home care and reduce inpatient hospitalizations altogether.
Pressures from payers to adopt value-based payment models and reimbursement changes also encourage hospitals to switch to outpatient settings.

Changes by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) have hastened the transition. CMS penalizes for excessive readmissions, incentivizing hospitals to keep patients away from extended inpatient stays. In 2021, CMS began phasing out its inpatient only list. Eliminating the list makes over 1,700 procedures eligible for Medicare regardless of inpatient or outpatient settings.

FAQs.question: How are you adapting your strategy to effectively reach and attract new patients?
FAQs.answer: With increasing competition, understanding how the company is targeting and acquiring new patients is crucial for sustained growth.

FAQs.question: What innovative strategies are you employing to differentiate your hospital's services and enhance brand awareness in the local community?
FAQs.answer: Hospitals often establish themselves in communities through fundraisers, community education and partnerships with other healthcare providers.

FAQs.question: What operational strategies are in place to streamline processes and improve efficiency, ultimately lowering costs and enhancing patient satisfaction?
FAQs.answer: Enhancing operational efficiencies is vital to deliver high quality care while maintaining financial viability.

FAQs.question: How do you actively engage hospital stakeholders, such as physicians and staff, in the strategic decision-making process?
FAQs.answer: Involving stakeholders in decision-making fosters a culture of collaboration and aligns strategic initiatives across the organization.

FAQs.question: What steps have you taken to protect patient data?
FAQs.answer: Hospitals have become a major target for cyber attacks because patient data is personal and could be valuable.

FAQs.question: How are you leveraging cutting-edge technology, such as electronic health records and telemedicine?
FAQs.answer: Adopting advanced technology solutions can lead to improved patient outcomes, streamlined workflows and cost savings.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure ongoing compliance with evolving healthcare regulations?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare regulations are subject to frequent changes, and staying compliant is crucial to avoid penalties and maintain the trust of patients and regulatory bodies. Regularly assessing and updating policies and procedures is essential for maintaining compliance.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure strict adherence to healthcare regulations and policies? What measures are in place to mitigate compliance risks and maintain patient trust?
FAQs.answer: Compliance with regulations is crucial to avoid legal issues, maintain accreditation, and safeguard patient privacy in the highly regulated healthcare industry.

FAQs.question: How do you optimize revenue cycle management processes to ensure timely and accurate billing, maximize reimbursements and mitigate financial risks?
FAQs.answer: Efficient revenue cycle management is essential for financial stability and maintaining optimal cash flow.

FAQs.question: What strategies are in place to control and minimize expenses while maintaining the highest quality of patient care?
FAQs.answer: Balancing cost containment with delivering exceptional care is a critical consideration for financial success and sustainability.

FAQs.question: How does the supply of healthcare professionals impact your ability to recruit and retain a qualified workforce?
FAQs.answer: Demand for healthcare professionals such as doctors, nurses, technicians and specialized healthcare workers often exceeds the available supply.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored consolidation or partnerships with other healthcare providers as a means of reducing operating costs?
FAQs.answer: Some healthcare providers have explored mergers and acquisitions to increase negotiating power with health insurance providers.

FAQs.question: Does your hospital maintain a strong reputation in its community?
FAQs.answer: Many hospitals operate on a local basis and can benefit from being a staple in the community.

FAQs.question: How do changes in federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid impact the financial stability and sustainability
FAQs.answer: Funding levels directly affect a hospital's budget, operations and ability to provide quality care. Understanding these impacts is crucial for hospital management to plan effectively, allocate resources and adapt to shifting financial landscapes.

FAQs.question: How does the growing number of adults aged 65 and older impact demand for services at your hospital? What measures are being taken to anticipate the impact of demographic changes on financial viability?
FAQs.answer: Anticipating the impact of an aging population helps hospitals adapt infrastructure, staffing and services to meet the specific needs of older adults to maintain financial health.

FAQs.question: What strategies does your organization implement to mitigate risks associated with changes in private health coverage rates?
FAQs.answer: Changes in private health coverage influence what hospitals receive in reimbursements. Reimbursements determine a hospital's financial health. Developing strategies to adjust to changes makes the hospital more resilient.
